entry.title: Re: Valuation Price Field Is Read-Only for Items Sourced...
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the new Fiori app F1639A (‚ÄúMy Purchase Requisitions ‚Äì New‚Äù) does not allow direct editing of the Valuation Price for catalog-sourced items. This is by design: once a catalog ID is attached, the price is locked to ensure compliance with the catalog contract. The earlier workaround (removing the catalog ID via BAdI) is not supported in the new app.

Below are Workarounds / Alternatives

Use non-catalog sourcing for editable price
If you need to override catalog pricing, source the item via manual entry or info record/contract reference instead of catalog. This keeps the valuation price field open for editing.

Custom logic via extensibility
In Public Cloud, only certain In-App Extensibility points are available. You can explore the BAdI to influence price determination. However, these typically allow substitution of source-of-supply pricing, not manual editing of catalog prices.

Workflow / approval route
If business requires adjusting catalog prices (e.g., negotiated discounts), best practice is to handle this via contract conditions or supplier catalog maintenance, not at PR level. You can set up workflow rules so that PRs with catalog items route for approval if the catalog price is not acceptable.

entry.title: Re: My First Situation with the Extended Framework
entry.content:
Hi @Ramjee_korada,

Let me answer your questions:

  1. Currently it is not possible to forward a situation to another user. Depending on your teams set up with Responsibility Management, the situation can be sent to multiple people. - relating to question 4 - if someone takes the situation the Assign to Me option can be chosen so that the others see that someone is already working on the situation.
  2. Situation Handling is meant to support users by alerting exceptional issues or also providing heads-up to upcoming deadlines. If there are tasks in the process that are mandatory or compliancy-relevant you should rather consider a workflow.
  3. The design of the situation page is explained in the blog post Configure the layout of My Situations ‚Äì Extended.
  4.  Situations are not assigned to a person per default. As stated above, a situation can be visible for multiple people. This is why the column is empty. Only if a user actively assigns the situation to themselves, the processor is visible.

Best
 Angelika

entry.title: Re: Purchase order accruals POAC and periodic billing plan
entry.content:
Why accruals behave this way is because, the POAC program calculates accruals based on delivery date and GR/SES postings at the item level. Even if you define a periodic invoicing plan with monthly billing dates, the accrual engine does not read those billing plan dates. It only looks at the delivery date of the PO item (or service entry sheet acceptance). That is why in your test:

  • Delivery date = 31/12 ‚Üí accrual = 0 until December.
  • Delivery date = 28/02 ‚Üí accrual = full 1200 in February.

For service materials, multiple deliveries are not possible, so you can‚Äôt split the PO item into monthly deliveries to align accruals.

Below are the workarounds / alternatives

Split PO items by period
Create 12 PO items (one per month, each with delivery date at month end, value 100). This way, POAC will accrue correctly per month. Downside: more PO lines to manage.

Use Service Entry Sheets (SES)
Post SES monthly for the service material. POAC will accrue based on SES acceptance dates. This aligns accruals with service consumption rather than delivery date.

Custom enhancement (BAdI / substitution)
Technically, you could enhance POAC logic to read billing plan dates instead of delivery date. This requires a custom development (e.g., BAdI FINS_ACCRUAL_POSTING or substitution in accrual engine). In Public Cloud, extensibility is limited, so this may not be feasible unless SAP releases a standard enhancement.

Alternative reporting
Instead of relying on POAC, build a custom accrual report that reads billing plan dates and calculates expected accruals. This can be done via CDS view on PurchaseOrderBillingPlan and PurchaseOrderItem. You‚Äôd then post manual accruals or journal entries based on this report.

entry.title: What is eCATT error TT377¬†Control data is obsolete, rerecord (&1&2&3) ?
entry.content:
I'm running an eCATT on an S/4HANA system (ABAP 7.58 SP 1) and I get the below error TT377:

Control data is obsolete, rerecord (VERBS-NAME: GETGUISERVICES CATT: GETDATAASFORMAT Callno: 000010)

The eCATT was created on an old ABAP system (ECC 6.0, ABAP 7.31) and it contains only one TCD command (Batch Input).

I see there are other same questions but with different VERBS-NAME (e.g. CREATEOBJECT), CATT (e.g. GETGUISERVICES, CREATE, <none>, SHOWDATA) or Callno, the answers were unclear what it means and what to do.

What means this message and how to solve it?

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: What is eCATT error TT377¬†Control data is obsolete, rerecord (&1&2&3) ?
entry.content:
The error message TT377 "Control data is obsolete, rerecord (&1&2&3)" means that the list of called OCX control methods (called "verbs") is different from the list of called OCX control methods when the eCATT was recorded:

  • The placeholder &1 ("VERBS-NAME") is the OCX control method ("verb") currently called.
  • The placeholder &2 ("CATT") is the OCX control method which was recorded at the time the eCATT was recorded, and which is expected.

For information:

  • The error message TT377 is sent by the function module CAT_CONTROLS_PLAYBACK.
  • The list of the recorded OCX verbs is stored in the table ECSCR_TVER.

I have no idea if this discrepancy between expected and actual verbs is critical or not, but by default it makes the script fail.

Solution

In my case, if I wrap the TCD command between the commands MESSAGE (MODE = 'A',  EXIT = <empty value>, MSGTYP = 'A', MSGID = 'TT', MSGNR = 377) and ENDMESSAGE (empty interface).

  • MODE = 'A' means "Allowed", i.e. if the message happens, there's no error, the next command inside the block MESSAGE/ENDMESSAGE is run, or if there's none the command after the block. For information, the standard behavior for the "A" (abort) error messages is MODE = 'F' (Failure),  EXIT = 'X' (execution skips to the ENDMESSAGE command).

If you don't want to use the block MESSAGE/ENDMESSAGE, you may rerecord the TCD command in the current system with exactly the same screens, and put back the original TCD command interface (for instance, type the variables manually).

For more information

About eCATT, see here: eCATT: extended Computer Aided Test Tool (BC-TWB-TST-ECA) | SAP Help Portal.

You may also refer to the list of all eCATT commands here: eCATT Command Reference | SAP Help Portal

NB: I'd be thankful to anyone who can explain the rationale of comparing the expected (when the TCD was recorded) and actual (when the TCD runs) lists of OCX control verbs.

entry.title: Re: eDocument Cockpit Incoming Supllier Invoice Colombia...
entry.content:
Analyzing the screens, the errors shown corresponds to the customer invoice not to the subsequent document (Acknowledge of invoice) sent to DIAN to verification.

The application when press "Check" creates the subsequent documents of acknowledge of invoice and receipt of goods, the information to create these new documents is extracted from the customer invoice that was uploaded, part of this information is the CUFE of the invoice.

 DIAN with the CUFE verify if the invoice was approved, if not return the rejection codes, this seems the case you report.

To verify if the invoice is approved and exists in DIAN site use the following links:

DIAN productive

DIAN Test

As final comments, taking in account this error codes do not belong to the process of incoming invoices, it seems to belong to the customer invoice process, our suggestion is to verify if the invoice is approved by DIAN and run again the incoming invoice process with an approved invoice, nevertheless you can post a case to SAP reporting any error.

Best Regards

Miguel Benitez

SAP Globalization Services

entry.title: Secure SAP‚ÄìAI Integration Using Advantco OpenPGP Services
entry.content:
Secure SAP‚ÄìAI Integration Using Advantco OpenPGP Services

1. Purpose and Scope

This article defines a secure, deployment-agnostic reference architecture for integrating SAP backend systems with external AI agents using OpenPGP-based cryptographic services provided by Advantco. The architecture separates cryptographic processing from data transport, ensuring that encryption, decryption, signing, and verification are performed by a dedicated cryptographic service layer, while message routing and orchestration remain the responsibility of the calling application or integration layer.

The architecture is intended for hybrid enterprise environments in which SAP backend systems may be deployed on-premise, in private cloud, on hyperscalers, or under RISE with SAP. AI agents may run on external platforms or managed AI services. Advantco OpenPGP services are exposed as APIs (REST and/or SOAP) and may be deployed on SAP Business Technology Platform or an equivalent enterprise runtime. This document describes a logical reference architecture and does not prescribe a specific deployment topology.

The scope of this document is limited to secure data exchange and trust establishment between SAP systems and AI agents. AI model behavior, prompt engineering, SAP business logic, and transport-level protocol selection are out of scope except where they affect security guarantees.

2. Architectural Rationale

Integrating SAP systems with external AI capabilities introduces a trust boundary between SAP-controlled environments and systems that operate outside SAP governance. This architecture addresses that boundary by enforcing message-level security that is independent of transport mechanisms and network topology.

Rather than embedding cryptographic logic into SAP applications or integration flows, the architecture externalizes OpenPGP operations into a dedicated cryptographic service layer. This allows encryption, decryption, signing, and verification to be centrally governed, audited, and evolved without requiring changes to SAP business applications. Transport and routing of messages remain the responsibility of SAP applications or integration components, preventing the cryptographic services from becoming an implicit integration broker.

3. Architectural Overview

The architecture consists of four logical concerns: SAP backend systems, an optional integration or orchestration layer, Advantco OpenPGP cryptographic services, and an external AI agent ecosystem.

SAP backend systems produce and consume business data but do not perform cryptographic operations directly. They rely on an integration or orchestration layer such as SAP Integration Suite, a SAP BTP application, or other middleware to coordinate message exchange with external systems where required.

Advantco OpenPGP services provide cryptographic transformation via APIs only. They do not perform message routing, transport, or forwarding.

External AI agents receive only signed and encrypted payloads and return responses in signed and encrypted form. Unencrypted payloads exist only within SAP-controlled trust boundaries.

Advantco OpenPGP provides cryptographic APIs only and returns results to the caller. Message transport and routing are handled by SAP or integration components and are not performed by Advantco.

4. Architecture Structure

From a business perspective, the architecture enables SAP processes to consume AI-generated insights without relinquishing control over data confidentiality or trust decisions. AI systems may influence SAP outcomes, but only after cryptographic validation and SAP-side authorization.

From an application perspective, the architecture separates responsibilities clearly. SAP backend systems focus on business logic. The integration or orchestration layer handles routing, retries, and protocol adaptation. Advantco OpenPGP services handle cryptographic transformation. AI agents handle AI processing only.

From an integration perspective, communication is message-based and transport-agnostic. Payload-level security is applied using OpenPGP before data crosses trust boundaries, ensuring that transport security is an additional layer rather than the primary protection mechanism.

From a data perspective, unencrypted payload exists only within SAP-controlled environments. Outside those boundaries, data is always exchanged in signed and encrypted form, accompanied by cryptographic metadata required for verification and audit.

5. Component Responsibilities

SAP backend systems remain the authoritative producers and consumers of business data. They initiate outbound requests and consume inbound results but delegate cryptographic processing to external services. SAP systems do not store or manage cryptographic private keys.

The integration or orchestration layer (where present) is responsible for transport, routing, protocol handling, retries, correlation, and error handling. It invokes Advantco OpenPGP APIs as required and forwards encrypted payloads to external AI agents, and returns verified payloads to SAP systems. It does not perform cryptographic operations beyond invoking the cryptographic service APIs.

Advantco OpenPGP services provide cryptographic operations as APIs. For outbound processing, they accept payloads and perform optional compression, message digest generation, digital signing, and OpenPGP hybrid encryption. For inbound processing, they accept encrypted payloads, verify digital signatures, decrypt content under governed key controls, and return verified payloads to the caller. These services are stateless with respect to message routing and do not forward data to external systems.

External AI agents operate outside the SAP trust boundary and are treated as untrusted by default. They can only process data that they have successfully decrypted and verified using trusted SAP public keys. AI agents sign and encrypt all outbound responses using their own private keys and do not receive access to SAP private keys or verified SAP payloads.

Key management is handled by a centralized Key Management Service that governs cryptographic key lifecycles, enforces usage policies, and records audit events. Agent identities are established by registering and allow-listing agent public keys, typically identified by fingerprints or key identifiers. Private keys remain protected and are never exposed outside the cryptographic service boundary.

6. Message Exchange

The Advantco OpenPGP APIs may be invoked directly by SAP applications or by an intermediate integration or orchestration layer. In all cases, Advantco performs cryptographic transformation only and does not forward messages.

In the outbound flow, SAP backend systems submit payloads for signing and encryption via the Advantco OpenPGP service. The service returns a signed and encrypted payload to the caller, which is responsible for forwarding the encrypted message to the external AI agent.

In the inbound flow, the external AI agent produces a signed and encrypted response. The encrypted response is submitted to the Advantco OpenPGP service for verification and decryption. The service returns a verified payload to the caller, which delivers the result to the SAP backend system.

The sequence diagram above illustrates the strict request‚Äìresponse nature of the Advantco OpenPGP APIs and the separation of cryptographic processing from message transport and routing.

7. Trust and Security Model

Trust in this architecture is based on cryptographic identity rather than network location. Public-key identities establish which parties may exchange data, while centralized key governance determines how keys may be used. By default, no shared secrets are required between SAP systems and AI agents.

Confidentiality is enforced through OpenPGP hybrid encryption. Integrity and authenticity are enforced through digital signatures. Auditability is provided through centralized logging of cryptographic operations. Replay protection is enforced by the receiving side using message identifiers, timestamps, and validity windows.

Cryptographic validity does not imply business authorization. AI-generated responses or instructions must still be validated against schemas, allow-listed actions, and SAP-side authorization rules before affecting SAP business processes.

8. Deployment Considerations

The architecture supports a wide range of deployment models, including scenarios in which SAP systems and integration components run on SAP BTP while cryptographic services are cloud-hosted and AI agents operate on external platforms. Security and correctness depend on logical separation of responsibilities rather than physical co-location.

As a concrete implementation option, Advantco OpenPGP services are available for deployment on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). In this model, the cryptographic services run as managed applications or services on SAP BTP and expose OpenPGP functionality through REST and/or SOAP APIs. SAP backend systems and SAP integration components can invoke these APIs directly using standard SAP-supported connectivity mechanisms. Deployment on SAP BTP does not change the logical architecture described in this document; Advantco OpenPGP continues to operate strictly as a cryptographic service and does not perform message routing or transport.

9. Conclusion

This reference architecture defines a clear separation between cryptographic services, message transport, and business logic for secure SAP‚ÄìAI integration. By exposing OpenPGP operations as governed APIs and keeping data transport outside the cryptographic service boundary, the architecture enables strong security guarantees while remaining flexible, deployment-neutral, and suitable for enterprise use.

10. Sources

https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform.html
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4880
https://owasp.org/www-project-api-security/
https://www.advantco.com/sap-integration-adapters/sap-pgp-integration

entry.title: Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management (TRM)
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog primarily introduces the configuration of Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management (TRM).

If anything regarding TRM account determination has not been clarified in this blog post, please leave a comment and we will try to refine it as soon as possible.

Foundational Knowledge

To fully engage with the content ahead, familiarity with the following foundational concepts is mandatory:

  • Basic knowledge in general ledger accounting, account receivables, account payables, e.g., document types, posting keys, account types (e.g., D - Customers, K - Vendors, S - G/L accounts).
  • Valuation areas in TRM and how they are linked to accounting principles and ledgers.
    • Paying valuation area is linked to the leading ledger.
    • Nonpaying valuation areas are linked to the non-leading ledgers.
  • Update types in TRM and how they are determined from valuation area-independent operational cash flows, valuation area-dependent business transactions (e.g., valuation, accrual, derived business transactions), etc.
  • Account assignment references in TRM and how they are derived.
  • TRM position management and position change categories.
  • Bank account management in cash management.

Configuration activities

Configuration activities (of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) or IMG activities (of S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition) will be used in this blog post:

 

Configuration activities in Public Cloud

Configuration Table

IMG activities in Private Cloud

102121 - Define Account Symbols

TRAC_ACCSYMB

TRAC_ACCSYMB_T

KONTENFINDUNG - Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management

103014 - Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management

TRAC_POSTRULE

TRAC_POSTRULE_T

TRAC_DFTRULE1

TRAC_DFTRULE2

TRACC_ACCSYMBREP

KONTENFINDUNG - Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management

105589 - Define Clearing Accounts for Cross-Country/Region Bank Account Transfers

ATPRA

FIBL_V_ATPRA_FI - Define Clearing Accounts for Cross-Country/Region Bank Account Transfers, or TR_IMG_PRQ_VZA - Define Clearing Account for Payment Requests

102097 - Set Effects of Update Types on Position Components

TRLAC_DFT_PMC

TR_FS_ART_BESTFTBETR - Set Effects of Update Types on Position Components

This blog post will be described in the context of public cloud.

TRM account determination logic at a glance

Evaluate the business requirement

Before starting configuration for account determination, please evaluate the business requirement for posting:

  1. What is the update type for which the posting should be generated? What is the economic essence behind it?
  2. What are the categories for the debit and credit entries of this posting? Is it a posting for position (book value) of the financial instrument, or customer or vendor subledger, or bank clearing account, or profit or loss account (with account assignment required like cost center), or others?
  3. What are the G/L account numbers should be used?

The order of configuration

  1. Define account symbols and specify the posting categories for the account symbols in configuration activity 102121. The available posting categories are:
    • 1 - Position Posting (Book Value) in Position Currency
    • 2 - Subledger Posting in Payment Currency
    • 3 - Bank Posting in Payment Currency
    • 4 - Profit-Related Posting in Position Currency
    • 5 - Profit-Related Posting in Payment Currency
    • 6 - Other G/L Posting in Position Currency
    • 7 - Other G/L Posting in Payment Currency
    • 10 - Currency Swap Between Position Currency / Payment Currency
    • 11- Tax Posting in Payment Currency
  2. Define posting specifications in node ‚ÄòDefinition of Posting Specifications‚Äô of configuration activity 103014, including document type, posting keys, account symbols, special G/L indicators (optional, only when posting to customer/vendor subledger) for debit and credit entries of the posting specification.
  3. Assign the posting specifications to the update types in node ‚ÄòAssignment of Update Types to Posting Specs‚Äô of configuration activity 103014.
  4. Assign the G/L accounts to the account symbols, account assignment references (optional, but usually needed for most cases), valuation areas (optional), currencies (optional) in node ‚ÄòAssignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols‚Äô of configuration activity 103014.
  5.  

A simple illustration

MM1150- is the update type of interest capitalization from the investment transactions of money market. MM1150- is assigned with the posting specification 13700, which can be seen from the node ‚ÄòAssignment of Update Types to Posting Specs‚Äô of configuration activity 103014.

In the node ‚ÄòDefinition of Posting Specifications‚Äô of configuration activity 103014, check the posting specification 13700:

  • Document type: SA
  • Debit entry: posting key 40, account symbol 1 (posting category: 1 - Position Posting (Book Value) in Position Currency)
  • Debit entry: posting key 50, account symbol 4.1.3 (4 - Profit-Related Posting in Position Currency)

The account symbols are created and their posting categories are specified in configuration activity 102121:

In the node ‚ÄòAssignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols‚Äô of configuration activity 103014:

  • Assign G/L account 18030000 (Long Term Investments, Unaffiliated(TRM)) to account symbol 1 and account assignment reference 201100000000.
  • Assign G/L account 70200000 (Interest Income, Unaffiliated(TRM)) to account symbol 4.1.1 and account assignment reference 201100000000.

Posting result: when running TBB1/TPM10 for the interest capitalization flow using update type MM1150- from an investment money market transaction with account assignment reference 201100000000, the posting journal entry would be debiting 18030000 and crediting 70200000.

Position posting (book value) in position currency

To post to the financial assets or liabilities reflected in the position accounts of the financial instruments, please use an account symbol with posting category 1 - Position Posting (Book Value) in Position Currency.

The position accounts of the financial instruments include (but are not limited to) the long/short term investment or debt arising from debt instruments (e.g., deposits, CDs, loans, bonds, ABS/MBS), equity investments (e.g., stock, shareholding), fund investments, derivative assets or liabilities from derivative financial instruments (e.g., forwards, options, swaps), receivables or payables arising from trade finance contracts like letter of credit, regardless of how the G/L accounts of positions are named in your chart of accounts.

Usually, if an account symbol with posting category 1 is involved in an update type where the position change category cannot be automatically determined, especially for the update type mapped to an operational cash flow from financial transactions or securities account management, the update type should be assigned with a proper position change category in the configuration activity 102097 - Set Effects of Update Types on Position Components, to ensure that the effects on position changes in TRM position management and position accounts postings are consistent.

Examples:

Bank clearing account or Payment request clearing account

This section elaborates the usage of posting category 3 - Bank Posting in Payment Currency. Let‚Äôs have a look at the following example:

In configuration activity 102121 - Define Account Symbols, account symbol 3 ‚ÄúBank clearing‚Äù is defined with posting category 3.

In the node ‚ÄòAssignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols‚Äô of configuration activity 103014, in the field ‚ÄúG/L account‚Äù, ‚Äú+++++++080‚Äù is assigned to the account symbol 3.

The posting spec 11100 is assigned to update type MM1100- (principal increase of investment transaction of money market). Posting spec 11100 credits account symbol 3.

Create an investment transaction for interest rate instrument. In the tab Payment Details, ‚ÄòWithout‚Äô is selected for ‚ÄúPayment Request‚Äù option of direction ‚Äúoutflow‚Äù, the house bank is DEBK1 and account ID is DEAC1.

In tab Cash Flow, the field ‚ÄúPayment Request‚Äù is empty for the principal increase flow as of 22.12.2025 (flow type 1100, direction ‚Äòoutflow‚Äô, update type MM1100-).

Run TBB1/TPM10 as of 22.12.2025. Check posting log:

The posting of MM1100- credits G/L account 0011001080.

How is 0011001080 determined?

System first finds out the G/L account of house bank DEBK1 and account ID DEAC1 of company code 1010, it is 0011001000 (the bank main account).

System them applies +++++++080 (the ‚ÄúG/L account‚Äù assigned to account symbol 3) to the bank main account 0011001000:

  • The first 7 digits of 0011001000‚Äî0011001‚Äîare retained because of +++++++
  • The last 3 digits of 0011001000 are replaced with 080
  • Combining 0011001 and 080 results in the bank sub-account (bank clearing account) 0011001080, which is then used for posting.

Let‚Äôs create another investment transaction for interest rate instrument. In the tab Payment Details, ‚ÄòWith‚Äô is selected for ‚ÄúPayment Request‚Äù option of direction ‚Äúoutflow‚Äù, the house bank is DEBK1 and account ID is DEAC1, the payer/payee and its partner bank (which are required in payment request) are also specified in the sub-area ‚ÄúPayment‚Äù.

In tab Cash Flow, the field ‚Äúpayment request‚Äù is ‚ÄúX‚Äù for the principal increase flow as of 22.12.2025 (flow type 1100, direction ‚Äòoutflow‚Äô, update type MM1100-).

Run TBB1/TPM10 as of 22.12.2025. Check posting log:

Now, the posting of MM1100- credits G/L account 21900000 (Payment Request Clearing Account (TRM)).

How is 21900000 determined?

When the ‚Äúpayment request‚Äù is ‚ÄòX‚Äô, system abandons the use of the bank clearing account. Instead, system retrieves the account maintained in configuration activity 105589 - Define Clearing Accounts for Cross-Country/Region Bank Account Transfers.

In TBB1, you can also check the payment log, in which you can find the payment request number.

Afterwards, please use the app Automatic Payment Transactions for Payment Request (transaction F111) to process the payment request, create accounting document debiting 21900000 and crediting bank clearing account (determined by payment program instead of TRM), and create the payment medium if necessary. The detailed process is not elaborated herein.

Summary:

  • Bank clearing account is used when the corresponding cash flow is without payment request.
  • Bank clearing account is usually applicable to the bank-initiated payments (for example, for most of the incoming payments), and the open item of bank clearing account should be later reconciled with bank statement item.
  • Payment request clearing account is used when the corresponding cash flow is with payment request.
  • Payment request is usually applicable to the corporate-initiated payment scenario, in which the corporate should inform the bank to proceed with the payment, e.g., via payment medium sent to bank.

Paying/Nonpaying valuation areas and Postings to customers or vendors

You may already aware that different posting specifications can be assigned to the same update type in the node ‚ÄòAssignment of Update Types to Posting Specs‚Äô of configuration activity 103014, differentiated by the second column ‚ÄúP‚Äù (‚ÄúPayment Transaction‚Äù) and third column ‚ÄúPosted in Pay. VA‚Äù. For example:

  • 11100 is assigned to MM1100- with ‚ÄúP‚Äù unselected and ‚ÄúNot Specified‚Äù specified for ‚ÄúPosted in Pay. VA‚Äù.
  • 71100 is assigned to MM1100- with ‚ÄúP‚Äù selected and ‚ÄúPaying Valuation Areas‚Äù specified for ‚ÄúPosted in Pay. VA‚Äù.
  • 81100 is assigned to MM1100- with ‚ÄúP‚Äù selected and ‚ÄúNonpaying Valuation Areas‚Äù specified for ‚ÄúPosted in Pay. VA‚Äù.

If ‚ÄúP‚Äù is selected, it means the intention is to generate posting to customer or vendor subledger (FI-AR / FI-AP). In this example, the purposes of 71100 and 81100 are to post to vendor in credit side.

The posting spec 11100 assigned to ‚ÄúP‚Äù unselected MM1100- has been explained in above section ‚ÄúBank clearing account or Payment request clearing account‚Äù, in which credit entry is posted to bank clearing account or payment request clearing account, not vendor or customer.

Details of posting spec 71100 and 81100:

  • 71100 is used for the postings in paying valuation area.
    • Credit entry‚Äôs account symbol is V.0 in this example, this account symbol must use posting category 2 - Subledger Posting in Payment Currency.
    • Credit entry‚Äôs posting key must be relevant to account type D (customer) or K (vendor). In this example, the posting key 34 is used, 34 is a posting key for account type K.
  • 81100 is used for the postings in nonpaying valuation areas.
    • Credit entry‚Äôs account symbol is V.0 in this example, this account symbol must use posting category 2 - Subledger Posting in Payment Currency.
    • Credit entry‚Äôs posting key must be relevant to account type S (G/L accounts), instead of account type D or K. In this example, the posting key 50 is used.

Let‚Äôs use the following example to illustrate the outcome of this configuration.

Create an investment transaction for interest rate instrument. In the tab Payment Details, ‚Äòto customer‚Äô is selected for ‚ÄúPosting‚Äù option of direction ‚Äúoutflow‚Äù, which means for outflows, the postings should post to customer or vendor. Although it is called ‚Äúto customer‚Äù, it can also post to vendor (actually it is controlled by posting key). In this example, because posting key 34 is used, and posting key 34 is relevant to account type K, it posts to vendor instead of customer.

In tab Cash Flow, the field ‚ÄúPayment Transaction‚Äù is ‚ÄúX‚Äù for the principal increase flow as of 22.12.2025 (flow type 1100, direction ‚Äòoutflow‚Äô, update type MM1100-), indicating that it should post to customer or vendor. And the business partner entered in the field Payer/Payee (10537001 in this example) in sub-area ‚ÄúPayment‚Äù should be the customer or vendor.

Run TBB1/TPM10 as of 22.12.2025 for all valuation areas (paying and nonpaying valuation areas). Check posting log:

Because 1100 cash flow is ‚ÄúPayment Transaction‚Äù = ‚ÄúX‚Äù and DE0 is the paying valuation area, MM1100- uses the posting spec 71100 within DE0. 71100 uses the posting key 34 which is for vendor (account type K), so system knows that it should post to the vendor 10537001 (the business partner entered in the field Payer/Payee of payment details in the transaction). In above screen-shot of posting log, the G/L account of posting key 34 is empty (it is not a bug!), this is because the TRM accounting interface passes on the vendor account 10537001 to FI, and FI determines the reconciliation account from the vendor master data of 10537001. Checking the line item of the journal entry, you will see it credits the vendor 10537001, and its reconciliation account 21100000 is also determined by FI and stored in the line item. To ensure successful posting, the business partner 10537001 must be extended to the BP role FLVN00 (FI supplier) and the reconciliation account of vendor 10537001 must be maintained in advance.

Because 1100 cash flow is ‚ÄúPayment Transaction‚Äù = ‚ÄúX‚Äù and 002 and 003 are the nonpaying valuation area, MM1100- use the posting spec 81100 within 002 and 003. 81100 uses the posting key 50 which is for account type S, and from the screen-shot of posting log from TRM side, you already see the reconciliation account 21100000 has been determined in TRM.

How does TRM determine reconciliation account 21100000 for nonpaying valuation areas:

  • 81100 uses the account symbol V.0 with posting category 2, so TRM knows it should post to vendor or customer.
  • TRM checks the corresponding posting spec 71100 used in the paying valuation area, 71100 uses posting key 34 for account symbol V.0, posting key 34 indicates that the posting is done to vendor.
  • Then TRM determines that the 81100 should also post to vendor.
  • TRM finds out the reconciliation account 21100000 from the vendor master data of 10537001.
  • 81100 directly posts to 21100000 using posting key 50 (211000000 is provided in the TRM accounting interface to FI, and FI uses it for posting directly).

Therefore, the credit postings in all valuation areas are recorded in reconciliation account 21100000 of vendor 10537001.

A frequently asked question is that why different posting keys should be used for customer or vendor postings in paying and nonpaying valuation areas for the same update type. In other modules (e.g. FI-AR, FI-AP), the postings to customers or vendors can be done in all ledgers (leading and non-leading ledgers) at the same time without specifying a ledger group, so posting keys for account type D or K can be used in journals of all ledgers. TRM always performs the valuation area-dependent postings, that means, postings from paying valuation area are posted to the ledger group containing the leading ledger only, postings from a nonpaying valuation area are posted to the ledger group containing the corresponding non-leading ledger only. For leading ledger‚Äôs postings for customer or vendors, posting keys for account type D or K should be used (and later clearing can be performed); however, for the non-leading ledger only postings, posting keys for account type D or K are unacceptable (design of FI), that‚Äôs why it is needed to use posting keys 40, 50 (or other posting keys for account type S) for vendor or customer postings arising from the nonpaying valuation areas.

Additional notes:

  • As already stated, and emphasize again, whether posting to vendor or customer is decided by the account type of the posting key specified in the posting spec assigned to the update type with ‚ÄúP‚Äù selected and ‚ÄúPaying Valuation Areas‚Äù specified for ‚ÄúPosted in Pay. VA‚Äù.
  • The document type used for paying valuation area related posting spec should allow postings to account type D or K, if any account symbol in the posting spec uses posting category 2.
  • An account symbol with posting category 2 should be used exclusively with posting keys for either vendors or customers (not both) across all posting specifications. For example, if account symbol V.0 is already used with posting key 34 (account type K) in a posting spec, do not use V.0 with any posting keys for account type D (e.g., 01, 11) in other posting specs. Improper configuration of this kind will trigger error message TPM_TRAC1 040 ("Cannot determine account type for account symbol V.0") in TBB1/TPM10.
  • Postings to special G/L accounts are also possible. To achieve it, please configure posting specifications like below:
    • Posting spec of paying valuation area:
      • Use posting key 09 (debit) or 19 (credit) for customer
        • Specify a proper and available Special G/L indicator for customer (account type D)
      • Or, use posting key 29 (debit) or 39 (credit) for vendor
        • Specify a proper and available Special G/L indicator for vendor (account type K)
    • Posting spec of nonpaying valuation areas:
      • Use posting key 40 (debit) or 50 (credit) for customer or vendor
        • Use the same Special G/L indicator used in the corresponding posting spec for paying valuation area.
    • The mapping of special G/L accounts to reconciliation accounts should already be configured in FI for the special G/L indicators of account type D or K.
    • Account determination logic:
      • Paying valuation area: similar to reconciliation account posting, TRM passes on the vendor/customer account and special G/L indicator to FI via accounting interface, FI will determine the special G/L account.
      • Nonpaying valuation areas: also similar to reconciliation account posting, TRM checks the posting keys of corresponding posting spec of paying valuation area, determines it is for vendor or customer, finds out the reconciliation account, and determines the special G/L account of the reconciliation account and the special G/L indicator of account type D or K, pass on the special G/L account to FI posting.
  • The reconciliation account or special G/L account is used for vendor or customer related postings, and they are automatically determined (by FI for paying VA, or by TRM for nonpaying VAs), therefore, it is not necessary to assign and please do NOT assign G/L accounts to account symbols with posting category 2 in node ‚ÄòAssignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols‚Äô of configuration activity 103014.
  • There is another node ‚ÄúAssignment of Update Types to Posting Specs‚Äù (table TRAC_DFTRULE2) in configuration activity 103014, it is used to assign different posting specs for the same update type in different valuation areas and company codes, if necessary. Considering together with the node ‚ÄúAssignment of Update Types to Posting Specs‚Äù (table TRAC_DFTRULE1), the posting spec determination logic for an update type in a valuation area is like below:
IF posting spec is found in TRACV_DFTRULE2
  Use the posting spec found in TRACV_DFTRULE2
ELSEIF the valuation area is paying valuation area
  IF posting spec is found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = 'P' (paying valuation area)
    Use the posting spec found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = 'P'
  ELSEIF posting spec is found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = '' (not specified)
    Use the posting spec found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = ''
  ELSE
    Raise error message
ELSEIF the valuation area is NOT paying valuation area
  IF posting spec is found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = 'N'(nonpaying valuation area)
    Use the posting spec found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = 'N'
  ELSEIF posting spec is found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = ''
    Use the posting spec found in TRACV_DFTRULE1 with POST_IN_VAL_AREA = ''
  ELSE
    Raise error message

Profit-related postings

The posting category 4 - Profit-Related Posting in Position Currency or 5 - Profit-Related Posting in Payment Currency should be used for the account symbols assigned with the profit or loss G/L accounts which are set up as primary cost elements (cost element category 1 - Primary costs).

The primary cost element needs account assignments (e.g., cost center) during posting. Only with posting category 4 or 5, the account assignments in treasury position indicator will be passed on to accounting document line items.

A frequently seen issue: the cost center appears in the position indicator of a treasury transaction (via any workable means mentioned in blog post Account Assignment in TRM Financial Transactions - Cost Center). However, this cost center is not used for postings done by TBB1 or TPM10, and error message like ‚Äúaccount assignment can‚Äôt be determined for cost element‚Äù is raised. The cause could be that the relevant account symbols (assigned with cost element in node ‚ÄúAssignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols‚Äù) doesn‚Äôt use posting category 4 or 5.

Currency swap between position currency and payment currency

The usage of posting category 10 - Currency Swap Between Position Currency / Payment Currency is special. In this example, the account symbol 9.1.4 uses posting category 10.

Account symbol 9.1.4 is not used in any posting specs.

A technical clearing account 22549000 is assigned to account symbol 9.1.4.

In the names of posting categories, you always see ‚Äú‚Ä¶in payment currency‚Äù or ‚Äú‚Ä¶in position currency‚Äù, these indicate which currency is the transaction currency in accounting documents‚Äîpayment currency or position currency.

When a posting spec involves two account symbols posted in different currencies‚Äîone is in payment currency and the other is in position currency, then the account 22549000 will be automatically involved.

For example, the posting spec 11100 is assigned to update type MM1902- (which is capitalized charges). 11100 debits with account symbol 1 (posting in position currency) and credits with account symbol 3 (posting in payment currency).

Now assume the position currency of the transaction if USD (the principal and interest are paid in USD), however, the charge MM1902- is paid in EUR. Check the posting log for MM1902-:

MM1902- credits bank clearing account in the transaction currency EUR (=payment currency of this flow), but its debit side recognizes position which is posted in transaction currency USD (=position currency of this transaction). In this case, two accounting documents are created for MM1902-:

  • One uses transaction currency USD, debits position account and credits technical clearing account 22549000;
  • The other uses the transaction currency EUR, debits technical clearing account 22549000 and credits bank clearing account.

The technical clearing account 22549000 is involved in two documents, and it has identical amounts in valuation currency within two accounting documents.

This kind of handling is necessary because only one single transaction currency is allowed in one accounting document (design of FI).

Dear Community,

Need to Assign for Return Order (CBAR or CBRE) for Credit Memo.


--- Steps to Reproduce ---

1. Create a return order type through CBAR/CBRE, where we will use the reference document as an invoice document. 

2. Create Outbound Delivery and PGR 

3. Create Credit Memo (Accounting Impacted: the Revenue GL for Return is Debit, and the Reconciliation Account for Customer would be Credit).

Thank you for your inputs!

entry.title: Quality level is not resetting back from Skip to Normal as per DMR in SAP QM
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

Good day, 

I have situation where I am maintaining Dynamic Modification Rule (DMR) with 2 stages as per client requirement. Requirement is to have only 1 inspection lot which is deliverable and next all lots should be skipped for the day. So, I have configured state 10 with Normal inspection and if it is UD accepted than inspection will move to state 20 as skip lot state and rest period is 1 day and also max allowed period is 1 days for state 20 (skip lot).

Here the challenge is, " this is not working as expected on all the days. For a few days it is working fine and for some days quality stage is not re-setting back from skip state (20) to normal state (10).   

Does anyone have any idea what is causing and why the quality state level is not resetting back as per reset period. requesting you please advise on the check points to find the cause for stage is not resetting as per rest period.

entry.title: Re: ME21N Retention fields ‚Äì which CDS view contains them?
entry.content:
Hi,

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, the Retention field you see in Create Purchase Order ‚Äì Advanced is UI-only.

  • The field is not currently exposed

  • It is not part of the Purchase Order API

  • It is not extensible via: Custom fields (key-user extensibility), CDS view extensions or Badi.

Retention cannot be passed via the Purchase Order API in S/4HANA Public Cloud currently.

Since this is a system limitation, please log a customer influence request. The development team monitors these requests and if it is within the scope of implementation, this will be put on SAP Road Map Explorer.

  1. Get started by opening SAP Customer Influence SAP Continuous Influence sessions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 
  2. Register and accept the Terms of Use
  3. Choose a session of your interest
  4. Create and submit your improvement request
  5. Take a look at existing improvement requests and start voting and commenting

Thanks and regards,

Krithika

entry.title: Material ledger price difference settlement to non inventory account
entry.content:
Hello everybody, 

We have a scenario where the client wants to post all price differences for materials to a different account rather than to inventory offset account (Obyc BSX), but they want to have PUP price for those materials(3/S).

Since BSX is for all inventory postings, we can't change those account assignments for ML closing posting. 

The reason is it that they want to have a separate position in the balance sheet for variances/price differences, and maintain the inventory account with S price values. 

I know you can use LKW account modifier to post diffrences to different account, rather then the inventory one, but I'm not sure how this will affect the material itself. 

They want revalute inventory, but the closing posting from ML needs to post those variances to different accounts then inventory. Preferably to some balance sheet account associated with inventory itself 

Is this possible in standard SAP material ledger?

entry.title: Re: Moniter Material Coverage_Suppier
entry.content:
Dear @ISoma,

In Monitor Material Coverage app the Supplier Name / Supplier Number columns are populated only when the system can determine or already has a source of supply for the material/plant

A supplier is shown when at least one of the following is true:

1. A procurement element already exists with a supplier

  • For example: a purchase order, scheduling agreement schedule line or a purchase requisition that already has a source assigned vendor/outline agreement

2. MRP source determination can select a valid source of supply
During the planning run, the system searches for a valid source in this order:

  • Quota arrangement including source list entries with MRP indicator
  • Source list with MRP indicator
  • Scheduling agreement
  • Purchasing contract
  • Purchasing info record with automatic sourcing indicator

If none of these yields a valid source validity dates, not blocked, applicable org/plant, etc.), the supplier fields remain blank

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3531581

If multiple Purchasing Info Records exist, will they all be displayed?

No, the app will not list all possible suppliers/info records for a row. It shows the one source that MRP selected/assigned for that material/plant

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Contingent Worker/External to Employee Conversions through Onboarding
entry.content: We have a terrible process to handle contingent worker to employee conversions.  We track our contingent workers in EC through Work Orders.  The contingent applies to a job through the external career site (because they are not employees) and if offered the job, the recruiter initiates onboarding.  Typically, they come up in rehire validation/employment selection profile.  The onboarding admin does not accept the match and selects to proceed as new hire.  Now there are two records for this person.  The onboardee completes their onboarding tasks.  The onboarding admin downloads all of the documents, takes a print screen of the new hire validation/personal information data, cancels the onboarding and rehires them in using the Add New Employee.  When the rehire validation comes up, the admin selects rehire with new employment and then the records are combined.  The issue is the onboarding record leaves a cancelled record that needs to be purged.  If the onboarding admin forgets to remove the national ID, they cannot use the add new employee functionality and the purge becomes urgent.  With 1H 2025, SAP introduced the Legal Entity transfer.  We thought this would work for us, but because the contingent  worker applies on the external site to go through initiate onboarding so they can complete their compliance tasks.  They do not receive the Legal Entity Transfer Welcome Mail and cannot toggle between profiles because they did not apply internally.  Are any other customers having this issue.  Is the way you solved for it to allow CWs to apply through internal career site and if so, how do you assign the I-9 and other compliance tasks?  Any assistance is appreciated.

entry.title: My Journey Building a Mobile‚ÄëFriendly Fiori App Using AI and Vibe Coding
entry.content:
and saga continues...

Figure 1. Screenshots from mobile phone that show main app functionality

 

UPDATE from my previous posts:

https://blogs.sap.com/2016/08/16/build-your-own-sap-fiori-app-in-the-cloud-2016-edition/

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/kiko3-sap-fiori-user-administration/

Please read my previous blog so you can familiarize yourself and be up to speed with the current blog post.


My idea was to enable basic user‚Äëadministration tasks ‚Äî locking and unlocking users, setting a new initial password, and adjusting a user‚Äôs validity date ‚Äî to be performed directly from a mobile phone instead of requiring a laptop. This isn‚Äôt meant for everyday office use, but it‚Äôs extremely helpful in global companies with on‚Äëcall teams supporting users in multiple time zones.

A typical scenario for this app is when you‚Äôre away from your desk ‚Äî for example, sitting in a park or waiting at an airport ‚Äî and you suddenly need to perform one of these tasks. Instead of opening your laptop and spending 15‚Äì30 minutes connecting and navigating through the system, you can complete everything on your mobile device in under five minutes.

Your phone can first connect to the corporate network through a VPN app, and the 2FA code arrives on the same device. From there, you simply open the corporate URL linked to the Fiori app. After setting the new initial password and unlocking the user, you can immediately send an email notification containing the credentials you just generated.

This approach makes user‚Äëadministration tasks faster, more convenient, and perfectly suited for real‚Äëworld on‚Äëcall situations.

Let‚Äôs look at how a typical real‚Äëworld scenario usually unfolds ‚Äî and whether there‚Äôs room to improve the process. In most cases, it consists of just 2‚Äì3 simple steps.

Step 1

Ivana (SAP user): I‚Äôm locked out of the SAP system. Could you please unlock my user?
You: Your user has been unlocked.

‚Ä¶a few minutes later‚Ä¶

Step 2

Ivana (SAP user): Could you please reset my password and unlock my user again? It seems I forgot it.
You: Your user is unlocked and the new initial password is: XXXXXX.

‚Ä¶a few minutes later‚Ä¶

Step 3

Ivana (SAP user): My SAP user is no longer valid‚Ä¶
You: Please try now ‚Äî I‚Äôve extended your validity date for two weeks.

One thing that first came to my mind is when you unlocking user, adding additional check if validity date is in the past, also if you are setting new initial password for user that is already locked unlock it and also check if validity date is in the past. If you find that validity date is in the past show warning message about validity date, as showed in Figure 2.

 Figure 2. Screenshots shows setting new initial password, automatically unlocking and warning message for validity date in past 

When I started building this app, I had no idea there was a name for what I was doing. I was simply copying pieces of code from my custom Fiori app, pasting them into an AI chat window, and asking it to ‚Äúadd this‚Äù or ‚Äúfix that.‚Äù It felt a bit like having a super‚Äëfast coding partner who never sleeps and never complains.

Every time I uploaded a new version, I hoped it would work ‚Äî and sometimes it did. Out of 110 versions I tried, around 30 were perfectly fine. The rest were a mix of broken logic, misunderstandings, or classic AI hallucinations. In other words, about 27% of the time, things worked exactly the way I imagined.

But here‚Äôs the interesting part: even with all the trial and error, I managed to implement every single idea that came to mind. I would think of a feature, describe it to the AI, and a few minutes later I had a working version (or at least something close enough to refine). Only later did I discover that this whole approach actually has a name ‚Äî vibe coding ‚Äî and that many developers are already using it to speed up their workflow.

Looking back, the process wasn‚Äôt perfect, but it was surprisingly effective. And honestly, it was fun ‚Äî like building something together with an unpredictable but incredibly creative teammate.

I have always using new increment in version when uploading  (Name of SAPUI5 App) custom Fiori to avoid issue with cache.

SE38 -> /UI5/UI5_REPOSITORY_LOAD

 Figure 3. captures the different versions I uploaded as I worked through this entire process

Version History
Added SAP theme selection option
Added application logo
Implemented Lock/Unlock functionality with automatic refresh after each operation
Added unlock warning when the user‚Äôs validity date is in the past
Improved password reset flow: when setting a new initial password, the app automatically unlocks the user (if locked) and checks the validity date
Enhanced validity date handling: when updating validity, the app now suggests a default date 10 days from today and refreshes after saving
Added quick‚Äëfilter buttons:
 - Show Locked (users with uflag > 0)
 - Show Invalid (users with a validity date in the past)
Added SID/Client input field before the Search bar
Improved Search behavior: entering two or more characters automatically displays matching users
Added in ABAP code option to search by last name/surname

For demo and full functionality of this Fiori app, please check video on Youtube.

Conclusion

What began as an experiment turned into a practical tool that saves time, reduces friction, and makes on‚Äëcall support far more manageable. With AI‚Äëassisted development becoming more accessible, this is just the beginning. I‚Äôm excited to see how these new workflows will continue to reshape the way we build and interact with enterprise applications.

NOTE: All screenshots and the video were taken on an iPhone 17, using the Demo21 S/4HANA 2022 ‚Äì 01 (02/2023) FPS environment.

Feel free to share your thoughts on this article or suggest any features you‚Äôd like to see added to the app. üòÉ

entry.title: Why Bringing SAP to Agentic SDK via Regular MCP Server Is Not Good Enough
entry.content:
Advocating Technology

Let me name things properly ‚Äì we have lots of noise around AI. Companies are trying to jump into the technology because they think that Business AI is simple, that it is just a kind of ChatGPT that gets access to business data. Sounds simple, doesn‚Äôt it?

I strongly disagree! Bringing SAP data to an Agentic SDK, like Claude or SAP Joule, does not mean delivering Business AI. It is far away from even an understanding of business needs. I know, you start hating me üòä. And the only reason for the internal opinion in your head is that you are most probably one of the MCP bridge providers that think that wrapping APIs (I will not write ‚Äúdiscover OData via MCP Server,‚Äù because the whole SAP community will hate me :D), or wrapping SAP tables/views, or wrapping SAP function modules is the way to bring SAP data to Business AI. 

How many posts do we see now on LinkedIn where people are happy like kids seeing data from an agentic SDK, e.g. Claude Desktop, returned by OData that is called via an MCP Server and shown as a table. Wow-wow! A list of Purchase Orders! As a table! Based on my utterance! C‚Äômon people, we are not in 2017 when we, together with the SAP Conversational AI team, were happy to see such kinds of cases. Yes, 9 years ago it was innovation, not now. Why not post on LinkedIn that the same OData service draws an even nicer table in a standard SAP Fiori app showing a list of Purchase Orders with‚Ä¶ OMG‚Ä¶ DRILL DOWN!!! üòä

Why am I writing this? Just to emphasize that Business AI is an excellent technology that is now far beyond strange posts where people see SAP data in another UI than GUI or Fiori. Real Business AI returns investment, works autonomously, and understands data. For example, an AI agent that gets emails from customers with purchase orders from their systems confirming the deals we‚Äôve made with them. That AI agent posts those emails to SAP, creating Sales Orders, for sure not using OData. Why not? Because there are two EntitySet calls you need to do to create a Sales Order via OData, and you need to be able to simulate a batch call; otherwise, you will get lots of Sales Order headers in your SAP productive system when the OData call for Sales Order Items has failed.

 Pic.1 Example from LinkedIn Article ‚Äì Creating Sales Order via OData without Batch Mode

However, even creating a Sales Order from my example is not the biggest challenge for that AI agent.

The Biggest Challenge

SAP data and the ‚Äúbridges‚Äù we build to connect AI agents with SAP via ‚Äúregular‚Äù MCP servers, this is the biggest challenge we create for AI agents. Sometimes it seems that after allocating a really good business case, we are doing everything possible to push the AI agent to fail üòä.

SAP data preparation is the boring, but extremely essential, step here. We should think about what we feed to the AI agent when asking it to read an email and post a Sales Order in the SAP system. We need to give the AI agent a chance to query master data that is so essential for that AI automation scenario and allocate master data in a robust and reliable way, independent of how the customer names our services and products in their systems.

SAP Master Data Vectorization

Let‚Äôs see a simple example we have created using the ChatGPT UI showing how different AI agents will act if you prepare and only then bridge SAP data properly. We will use two MCP servers for this:

  • Regular MCP Server for SAP Data (any MCP server, we do not like to point fingers at someone‚Äôs solution; we‚Äôd like to advocate AI automation only)

  • Skybuffer AI MCP Server for SAP Data (here we have a data preparation layer where we vectorize SAP master data first)

 Pic.2 SAP Master Data Vectorization as a Data Preparation Step

See the Difference

Now let‚Äôs simulate a request from an AI agent that is working autonomously and has responsibility to create Sales Orders in an SAP production system with the maximum level of automation.

Here is a simple example of a regular MCP Server failure, just because the customer captured data in their system a bit differently from our SAP productive system:

Pic.3 Regular MCP Server for SAP Data ‚Äì Failing on the Simple Case of Small Wording Differences

And now let‚Äôs see how easily and robustly an AI agent gets information from the same SAP system, but via an MCP Server that reads prepared SAP master data for AI automation:

 Pic.4 Skybuffer AI MCP Server ‚Äì Easy and Robust Access to SAP Master Data

Now you see that 99% of all examples or success stories from LinkedIn about how fast we can create MCP servers to bridge SAP data and how reusable OData services are, are solutions that are far away from productive implementation (unless you are OK with getting a 50% automation rate üòä).

Conclusion

Indeed, MCP servers that consume OData, tables/views, etc. make sense for some steps in AI automation. However, we need to be very careful, and we should not mix hype with productive implementations. A good MCP server bridges prepared SAP data that an AI agent can consume to provide a maximal rate of automation that will reach 100% in a short time of productive usage. Saving on implementation ruins the impression of Business AI and reduces trust in it. Let‚Äôs not harm our overall revenue and investment return, and think twice whether the bridge we build for an AI agent suits the goal.

Imagine connecting the Skybuffer AI MCP Server to SAP Joule, making it able to understand user input by similarities. How powerful would your SAP Joule implementation be, and how smoothly would SAP Joule understand requests? Skybuffer AI runs on SAP BTP, providing a hidden but necessary layer for SAP Joule that can properly bridge your SAP on-premise data.

Closing Statement

Good luck with AI automation implementations, and do not hesitate to ask questions, collaborate, and bring technology to customers in a way they benefit from it, not just seeing the hype in it.

entry.title: How does Effort Deviation adjustment persist across periods when Forecast Month changes?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am analyzing the CDS view I_EngmntProjFcstCube_2 in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and have a question about how ActualPlanDeviationEffort is calculated across multiple periods when the Forecast Month changes.

Background

According to KBA 3617498, when a Forecast Month is set, the system calculates Effort Deviation based on the difference between Planned Effort and Actual Effort, and an adjustment value is applied during this calculation (related to ETC/EAC logic).

My Question

I am trying to understand what happens to this adjustment value when the Forecast Month moves from one period to the next:

Scenario:

  • Month 1 (e.g., May 2024): Forecast Month is set ‚Üí Deviation adjustment is applied ‚Üí ActualPlanDeviationEffort = X

  • Month 2 (e.g., June 2024): Forecast Month moves forward ‚Üí New deviation is calculated

Which of the following happens?

Option A: Reset and Recalculate

  • The adjustment applied in Month 1 is reversed/cancelled

  • A fresh adjustment is calculated for Month 2 based on current Planned vs. Actual

  • Each period's deviation is independent

Option B: Cumulative/Persistent

  • The adjustment from Month 1 remains/persists into Month 2

  • Additional adjustments in Month 2 are added on top of Month 1's adjustment

  • Deviations carry forward across periods

Option C: Distributed

  • The adjustment is redistributed evenly across all remaining periods up to the Forecast Month

  • As mentioned in the documentation, adjustments are distributed across demands for the same role

Why This Matters

In our data, for period 2024005:

  • PlndEffortQty = 35

  • ActlEffortQty = 2

  • Expected deviation: 2 - 35 = -33

  • Actual ActualPlanDeviationEffort: -28

The difference of 5 hours seems to be an adjustment, but I cannot understand whether this adjustment was applied once in period 2024005, or if it's affected by adjustments from previous periods.

Has anyone worked with this logic or can point me to documentation that explains the period-by-period behavior of these deviation adjustments?‚Äã

entry.title: SAP + Microsoft 365: A Unified AI Experience That Works Where You Work
entry.content:
We‚Äôve all experienced it: you‚Äôre reviewing data, a message pings, an email comes in, and suddenly you‚Äôre juggling inboxes, chats, and screens just to finish one workflow. Those small interruptions feel routine ‚Äî yet employees switch between apps‚ÄØover 1,200 times per day, adding up to‚ÄØweeks of lost productivity each year.1 

It‚Äôs not the work that‚Äôs slowing us down. It‚Äôs the constant friction of moving between where the data lives and where communication happens. 

That‚Äôs why, building on SAP and Microsoft‚Äôs long-standing partnership, the new bi-directional integration between Joule and Microsoft 365 Copilot ‚Äî now generally available ‚Äî is designed to help people stay focused and get more done in the tools they already use. 

By bringing SAP business context and Microsoft 365 collaboration together into a unified experience, work can now keep flowing wherever it starts. Customers are already seeing an impact. 

‚ÄúThe integration of Microsoft‚ÄØ365‚ÄØCopilot and Joule is central to Vodafone‚Äôs vision of creating an end-to-end, AI-enabled user experience,‚Äù‚ÄØsaid Andrea Schiavi, Vodafone, AI Product Lead. 

"By unifying SAP business data with the Microsoft 365 productivity tools, we will create a seamless, intelligent workflow that accelerates decision making and boosts productivity. It will elevate our agentic assistant, AskHR, with shared context across apps so it can guide employees more effectively and resolve tasks faster.‚Äù 

One AI that follows the work ‚Äî not the other way around 

When you‚Äôre in Microsoft 365,‚ÄØCopilot‚ÄØcan access SAP processes and data through Joule. 
When you‚Äôre in SAP,‚ÄØJoule‚ÄØcan draw on information from Microsoft 365 through Copilot. No switching apps, just continuity. 

For example, a finance manager working in Microsoft Excel can use Microsoft 365 Copilot and @mention Joule to review a purchase order directly in the spreadsheet.  Joule retrieves‚ÄØreal-time SAP business data‚ÄØbehind the scenes, enabling a confident decision ‚Äî without opening another screen. 

Later, reviewing that purchase order inside‚ÄØSAP, the same finance manager can ask‚ÄØJoule‚ÄØwhether any recent‚ÄØemails or Teams messages‚ÄØcontain information that should be considered before confirming the approval. Copilot brings that context into SAP automatically, so nothing gets missed. 

Wherever the task begins, the right assistant shows up with the context needed to finish it. 

How it works 

  • In Microsoft 365 Copilot ‚Äî within Teams, Word, PowerPoint, Excel, and OneNote: @mention‚ÄØJoule‚ÄØto instantly access SAP insights and complete SAP tasks ‚Äî with prompts, feedback, and citations. 
  • In SAP apps: ask‚ÄØJoule‚ÄØyour question; when Microsoft 365 context is relevant, Joule automatically routes to‚ÄØMicrosoft 365 Copilot‚ÄØ‚Äî bringing in data from email, Teams, SharePoint, or OneDrive. 

No new interface to learn. The right assistant answers based on where you are. See Joule and Microsoft 365 Copilot integration in action! 

Why this matters and why it‚Äôs here now 

Work has evolved. SAP remains the trusted source of business truth, and Microsoft 365 is where collaboration happens. Bringing AI assistance across both environments simply helps people work the way they already do ‚Äî with fewer interruptions, faster decisions, and the confidence that every action is grounded in the right business and communication context. 

Get started today 

To begin using the Joule and Microsoft 365 Copilot integration, start by downloading the SAP Joule app from Microsoft Marketplace and configuring the connection between SAP Cloud Identity Services on SAP BTP and Microsoft Entra.  

You will need Joule base and a Microsoft 365 license to enable the integration. A Microsoft 365 Copilot license is required only when using Copilot skills within Joule. 

To learn more about the Joule and Microsoft 365 Copilot integration, visit the SAP Discovery Center.

entry.title: Re: My colleagues are not able to raise the case from htt...
entry.content: Hello customer, In order for user to raise case in SAP for Me, user needs S-user created under your customer number also the case related authorizations assigned to their S-users. Kindly contact the super user or user admin in your company to create new S-users for them as per the detailed steps introduced in KBA 1271482. To check the super user or user admin in your company, kindly access the My Important Contacts page. And the case related authorizations are documented in KBA 3383142. Also please the super user or user admin to assign the authorizations to the new S-users per KBA 1511008 . Hope the above information helps. Thanks and best regards, SAP Support
